dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: You can put your weapon away. You're not interested in us. The Young Iraqi points the gun at Bob who starts to walk towards the truck.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (firmly) Stay where you are Bob. Bob stops.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Shit...shit...

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (to the Iraqi, calmly) We can go about our business. Apparently having had enough one the Insurgents pulls his own GUN out and aims at Lyn. The tension builds. Suddenly Bob remembers the phrase he was taught.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (blurting) La termi, ana sahafi! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Immediately everyone stares at Bob. The Insurgent OPENS FIRE at him. Terrified Bob, dives across the sand. The Young Iraqi behind him also scrambles for cover. Still firing, the Insurgent is suddenly aware of Lyn sprinting towards him. Before he can turn to aim at him, Lyn LEAPS into the air, spinning around, face contorted as he emits a bizarre SHRIEK. We FREEZE-FRAME ON HIM, HUNG IN MID-AIR. BOB (CONT’D) (V.O.) (CONT'D) Now at the time I thought Lyn was having some kind of fit here. Later I discovered what he was actually doing was performing the Echmeyer technique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a man who looks like WOODY ALLEN in a jungle hat. He has his eyes closed in IMMENSE CONCENTRATION. A bead of sweat runs down his face. SUPERED TITLES read: BEN ECHMEYER.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ben Echmeyer was a Vietnam vet with sixty-three confirmed kills. He remains the only non-Korean to achieve the rank of Master in Kwa Ra Do. He was one of the Jedi teachers at Fort Bragg.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: SHOOTING from behind Ben to the rows of JEDI RECRUITS watching with expressions of mingled admiration and horror.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was said he could have a tug of war with a dozen men and not move an inch. We PAN DOWN the back of BEN and find he is NAKED from the waist down. A SAND BAG is somehow hanging between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was also able to lift bags of sand on hooks hung through his scrotum. A RECRUIT raises a hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JEDI RECRUIT
dialogues.text: Sir, what’s the practical application of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER-HEAD SHOT - Ben lies on the ground staring up at us. We hear the sound of an approaching engine.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Another demonstration involved letting a recruit drive a jeep over him. This, in the end, was to be his undoing. Next second a JEEP roars straight over Ben, going at sixty miles an hour. We FREEZE FRAME on the JEEP.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Before his untimely death Ben caused quite a stir by advocating his controversial “shock and awe” knife attack method. INT. DOJO —- DAY 92 Ben leaps spastically in the air, spinning and shrieking, a knife held in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The approach was hailed by some knife aficionados as revolutionary but criticized by others who believed that the leaping and spinning might lead you to accidentally stab yourself. TRACKING ALONG BEN’S TRAINEE JEDIS - as they watch his display.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lyn Cassady, however, became a firm convert to the style. We reach LYN who TURNS TO CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Ben, you’re not forgotten. The knife you gave me lies next to my beret. God bless Ben Echmeyer.  93 94 10/21/08 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We UN-FREEZE ON LYN - as he whirls and shrieks towards the Insurgent. Bob watches amazed from where he lies on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course, Lyn didn’t actually have a knife with him at this particular time...so I still think what he did was kinda...reckless. The Insurgent, understandably startled, flinches backwards, trips over the water bottle and falls on his ass. Lyn scoops up the gallon bottle of water and begins to POUND the fallen man with it. The Young Iraqi moves to intervene but Lyn smacks him in the face with the bottle. The BLINDFOLDED IRAQI IN THE TRUCK manages to open the door and stumbles out, claws his blindfold off and races away over the sand. The second Insurgent is distracted for a moment by his victim’s flight. When he turns back Lyn has scooped up the Insurgent’s GUN and is aiming it at him. Beat. Nobody moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is rising as the PICK-UP TRUCK roars over the sand and swerves onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE TRUCK
dialogues.text: Lyn drives. Bob is leaning out of the window, staring at the road behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (pulling his head back in) They’re not coming! We’re okay! Oh God, we’re gonna be okay! The Truck crests a hill and we see the IRAQI MAN running desperately down the road ahead of us, his hands tied.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: There he is. He puts his foot down and the truck roars after the running man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TRACKING SHOT - pulling the IRAQI MAN, running for all he’s worth. Lyn leans out of the truck window as he drives up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (yelling over the engine) Sir? You’re okay! We’re Americans. We're here to help you! Terrified the Man sprints faster. Lyn tries to pass him, but the Man veers at the same time and the truck CLIPS him, sending him flying.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TRUCK
dialogues.text: LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) Oh crap!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (braking) I think I just ran him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn runs over to where the MAN lies moaning on the road, his head bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Sir? Are you okay? (Beat) Bob, give me a hand here will you? Bob gets out and the two lift the Iraqi Man and begin to carry him back towards the truck. They stop listening to an approaching rumble.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh shit! Oh shit, they’re coming! They scuttle faster back towards the truck, the Iraqi Man dangling between them. Next second, two GLEAMING WHITE SUVs crest the hill and roar towards them. Seeing the road blocked by the truck, the SUVs screech to a halt and several MEN IN FLAK JACKETS AND SUNGLASSES tumble out in formation, aiming their M-16’s at Lyn and Bob. ARMED MEN’S P.O.V - Lyn and Bob stare at them before dropping the bound Iraqi on the ground. Bob waves nervously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We hear the opening of a period song as we...

dialogues.speaker: LAPTOP SCREEN
dialogues.text: We’re rushing over a CGI DESERT, between the CGI rivers Tigress and Euphrates towards a GLEAMING CITY rising from the sand.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then I say “There it is. The Future!" Bob and the Iraqi Man sit beside TODD NIXON - a suit. Lyn sits behind in between two of the PRIVATE SECURITY GUARDS, who are nodding along to the music playing in the car. Nixon, holding the LAPTOP for Bob to see, watches the screen, moved.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We play this on these big screens at the conferences, you know? This trumpet music blasting out. Every time I see it, it gets me. He glances over at the Iraqi Man who is holding a dressing to the cut on his forehead, pale and shaken.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You a businessman, sir? The Iraqi Man nods.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ali Babas have been targeting locals lately. (Holding out his hand) Todd Nixon, Army Small Business Office.

dialogues.speaker: IRAQI MAN
dialogues.text: (shaking) Mahmud Daash.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Ask me what business I'm in, Muhammad.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: (weakly) Mahmud. What business are you in sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Right now, I’m in the Quality of Life business. Nixon nods, smiling, pleased with the line.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (To Bob) We've got 25 million Iragis out here who wanna be independent, wanna make something of their lives. But more than anything else they wanna buy stuff. Cell phones, digital cameras, leisure suits - you name it. If it sells in Boston, then we can damn well sell it in Baghdad! (To Mahmud) Am I right Muhammad? (To Bob) He knows what I’m talking about. We’ve got Halliburton, Parsons, Perini...just in the primes. We’re gonna have Macdonalds, we're gonna have Starbucks...No corporate tax. It’s a gold-rush. Oh, and by the way, fuck the French! (Laughing) Did you hear that shit? Chirac wants to bring French contractors in? Can you believe that? Hey, Phil? Raise one hand if you like the French.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVER
dialogues.text: (their double act) Raise both your hands if you are French! He raises both his hands.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: (laughing) Yeah, okay...watch the wheel Phil. (To Bob) Year Zero boys. Bob nods politely.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK SEAT
dialogues.text: Lyn prepares an INJECTION for himself. He feels the Security Guard beside him watching. He notices the name of the company on the man’s badge - Krom Security.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (making conversation) What’s Krom? The Security Guard continues to watch him through his mirrored shades. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: (Texan accent) God of War.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (interested) Really? Is that Norse?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Conan the Barbarian. S’in the movie. Lyn injects himself.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Right. Lyn notices the Chilean Security Guard on his other side has a tattoo on his arm - “Viva Pinochet!"

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Okay. We’re in Indian Country. Check six. The SUV’s are approaching a town and other cars have appeared on the road. The Security Men on either side instantly lean out of their windows with their M-16’s - aiming them at the cars which swerve out of their way in fear.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: (To Bob) I was pretty down for a while about not getting any trigger time in this war Bob, but you know what I’ve learnt? Our greatest weapon against evil is commerce. When these people have quality consumer items they will no longer want to kill Americans. He turns to gaze at the TOWN they are now driving into.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna rest until there’s a satellite dish on every one of those roofs. Behind him the sound of CARS BRAKING AND SWERVING continues.  97 98 99 10/21/08 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG line of cars are waiting for gas - Iraqi men, women and children, suffering in the heat. Many of them have been there for hours. The SUVs approach.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE SUV 98
dialogues.text: The driver of the first SUV radios Nixon’s car.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (Over radio) We've got a line for the gas station here. Are we waiting?

dialogues.speaker: NIXON'S DRIVER
dialogues.text: (into radio) Negative. We'd be way too exposed. We’re taking the station. Go in fangs out. He accelerates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +..as the two SUV’s roar up, horns blaring, M-16’'s bristling from the windows. The lead SUV rams the car at the head of the line and sweeps it out of its path. Nixon’s SUV barrels through the gap and screeches to a halt by the pumps. The THREE SECURITY MEN roll out showily, machine guns ready.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Secure the perimeter! The men fan out to the corners of the station, while the first SUV blocks the road and more SECURITY pile out, guns raised to cover the line of cars. There are howls of protest from the waiting Iraqis. Inside the SUV Bob, Lyn and Mahmud watch in astonishment. TEXAN SECURITY MAN (CONT’D) Give her the go-juice, Eddy!

dialogues.speaker: CHILEAN SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: I filled her up last time.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: (cheerfully, out of the window) He did fill her up last time Gary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: With respect sir, bull-fucking- shit. I tanked her last time.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Every time! Can we get some sort of fucking system so we don’t... We hear a sudden, sharp POPPING sound. Immediately the Men drop into CROUCHES, scanning the area.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAN SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: (yelling) Contact! We’ve got contact! He opens FIRE - IMMEDIATE CHAOS: people scream, duck down, some cars reverse desperately and collide with the cars behind. The other Security Men join in the shooting.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: (shooting) Where? Where’s the shooter?

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET 100
dialogues.text: Another SUV - identical, but black, is passing, hemmed in by traffic. A stray BULLET from the gas-station pings off it’s armor plating. Immediately it screeches to a halt and a NEW DETACHMENT OF SECURITY MEN roll from the car - same flak-jackets and Oakley sunglasses but different color uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: NEW SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: (into radio) Contact! We’re under fire! The New Detachment open FIRE blindly in the general direction of the Station.

dialogues.speaker: GAS STATION 101
dialogues.text: .-.--as bullets smack off the parked SUV.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Two o'clock! Two o'clock! All the Security Men turns and begin spraying bullets across the road. Car windshields and windows explode.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE SUV
dialogues.text: A scowling Nixon has slid low in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trying to help you fucking savages. Mahmud, Bob and Lyn are lying flat on the seats.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: My house is not far. We could walk from here. Bob flinches as another bullet ricochets off the SUV.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sounds good Muhammad.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: Mahmud.

dialogues.speaker: GAS STATION 102
dialogues.text: As machine-gun fire from across the street strafes the station and Nixon’s Security men return fire blindly.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: (yelling into Radio) Krom One this is Freedom Frontier. We are under attack. This is a FUBAR situation. Requesting Kiowa! Behind him Lyn, Bob and Mahmud crawl across the station on their hands and knees, bullets zipping past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahmud leads Bob and Lyn at a crouching run down the street, amongst the crowd of Iraqis fleeing the gunfire behind them. We hear the whup-whup of a helicopter as a Kiowa Warrior passes over head. Moments later we hear an EXPLOSION as the helicopter opens fire with a MISSILE... INT. MAHMUD’S HOUSE - EVENING 104 TRACKING along a wall, past a crooked WEDDING PORTRAIT - a smiling Mahmud and WIFE, the glass broken...

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Muhammad led us to his home which it turned out had been robbed in his absence. We TRACK past a row of BULLET HOLES in the wall, a section of smoke damaged wall paper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOB (CONT’D) (V.O.) (CONT'D) And also accidentally set on fire by a US tank. Neighbors told him his wife had left, they weren’t sure where she had gone. We reach Bob, Lyn and Mahmud eating at a low table. The windows behind them have been partially boarded up. Mahmud is sunk into a profound depression. Lyn looks tired, pale. They eat in awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: Taameeyah.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: They’re really good. Bob nods politely. Mahmud nods, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I understood he was going through a lot, but considering we had saved him from kidnappers I still thought his welcome could have been a little warmer. Lyn clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry for running you over, sir. Mahmud shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Beat) And I apologize for that security detachment. Please don’t think all Americans are like that. Mahmud nods. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: I apologize for the kidnappers. Lyn demurs softly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Not your fault sir. I mean we get kidnappers in America too, so...you know. There’s always, uh, bad apples, right? The men eat in silence for a moment. Mahmud stares blankly at his plate, looking crumpled and lost. Bob watches him, faintly irritated. Lyn tries to think of something comforting to say.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (carefully) Akhir il ahzan. (May this be the last of your sorrows.) Mahmud looks at him, startled perhaps by the unexpected Arabic phrase. LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) Did I say it wrong? Mahmud shakes his head, moved but embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMUD DAASH
dialogues.text: No...that was right. They eat in silence. INT. MAHMUD’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT 105 Lyn and Bob are sharing a bed. Bob looks out of the window and notices a CLOUD over the moon. He concentrates on it, trying to “bust” it. Nothing happens. He sighs, looks over to Lyn who is staring at the wall, lost once more in dark thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Lyn?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Just Mahmud. People try to build something of their lives, something lasting, something good... but there’s always someone wants to smash it up...

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lyn was thinking of Larry Hooper and the part he had played in the destruction of the New earth Army. But, in fairness, the Jedis’ own eccentricities hadn’t exactly won them many allies in the Army. A JEDI - TIM KOOTZ - lies on the couch in a TRANCE, Bill sitting beside him with pen and paper.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For example, there was Tim Kootz who, on being asked to ascertain the whereabouts of General Manuel Noriega, had replied... Tim jerks awake from his trance.

dialogues.speaker: TIM KOOTZ
dialogues.text: (firmly) Ask Angela Lansbury.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (beat) What’s that Tim?

dialogues.speaker: TIM KOOTZ
dialogues.text: Ask Angela Lansbury. Bill looks up to an CIA AGENT observing from the next room. The Agent frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill waits a little anxiously. The CIA Agent walks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: CIA AGENT
dialogues.text: We asked Angela Lansbury.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: CIA AGENT
dialogues.text: She said she didn’t know where General Noriega was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR GENERAL JACK GILLING is being driven through the base. As he stares out of the window his expression suddenly changes to one of amazement. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or there was the time Major General Gilling was visiting the base and saw Jedi trainee Clifford Hickox... RUSSELL’S P.O.V - we are driving past the training course. A bare-chested, long-haired Hickox is dancing around a wooden pole to which he is attached by two long wires and metal hooks which are stuck in his bleeding nipples.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +..-practising the ancient Sun Dance of the Sioux Nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill is introducing a young, fresh-faced recruit - LIEUTENANT NORM PENDLETON to the other Jedis.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Jedis survived such minor scandals, protected, it was rumored, by a President who was a fan of both the Star Wars films and the paranormal himself. But then, one summer, a young, likeable Lieutenant called Norman Pendleton was recruited to the New Earth Army... Larry Hooper examines the new recruit with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Norm are jogging together, deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Larry Hooper wasted no time befriending the newcomer. Desperate to compete with Lyn, Larry had been doing research into the infamous CIA MK-ULTRA experiments which he believed could enhance his own psychic powers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm sits on the couch, smiling innocently as Larry wheels an ELECTRONIC DEVICE on wheels over to the couch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All he needed was a lab rat to try them out on, check if they were safe. Larry, making sure Norm can’t see, is pouring a massive dose of LSD into a DRINK. He gives the glass a quick stir and turns, smiling, to Norm with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm lies tripping on the couch, rigid, wide-eyed, wearing headphones, connected to the electronic device, which emit disturbing electronic frequencies. Larry stands at the light switch, turning the red bulb overhead on and off, eagerly watching Norm’s reaction - a modern day Frankenstein.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It turned out they weren’t.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: ...cowering terrified under the couch, as the sound of GUNSHOTS fill the room. Norm’s NAKED LEGS stride past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NAKED AND DEMENTED NORM walks through the base, firing random shots at scattering soldiers with his Beretta. He finds Bill blocking his way.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (gently) Norm? Give me the gun, Norm. Norm starts to cry. Then he puts the gun into his mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm's father - MAJOR GENERAL PENDLETON - stares fixedly to where Bill and Brigadier General Hopgood sit in the hearing - his expression filled with icy rage.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Norm’s father, who it turned out was pretty high up in the Pentagon, wanted blood. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Although the Jedis were pretty sure Larry was responsible, nothing could be proved and when he was called to the disciplinary hearing Larry made sure to smear Bill with everything he could...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY TALKING BEFORE THE HEARING 117
dialogues.text: ...looking every inch the neat, professional soldier.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel Django used funds from the project's black budget to procure prostitutes... The OFFICIALS listening register shock and dismay. Bill stands up, outraged.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: That's a lie!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: -..and also drugs for himself and his men. Bill jumps to his feet again.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: That’s a...(catches himself) Well the hooker thing is definitely a lie! The OFFICIALS look at him as if he were SATAN himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Brigadier General Hopgood resigned and died some years later. Bill received a dishonorable discharge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, a broken man, is walking off the base. He reaches the gates and sees Lyn waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: Continue the work, Lyn. The World needs the Jedis, now more than ever. Lyn can’t speak. Bill hugs him and walks off, the gates closing after him.  120 121 122 123 124 10/21/08 74. INT. FORT BRAGG - BARBERSHOP —- DAY 120 The Jedis sit having their hair shaved with electric clippers. The Jedi’s NEW COMMANDER - MAJOR HOLTZ - not a shred of New Age sympathy in his regulation heart - walks down the line, examining his men coldly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After Bill left, Major Holtz of Special Forces took command of the Jedis. Lyn stares at his reflection as his long hair falls to the floor. BOB (CONT’D) (V.O.) (CONT'D) And nothing was ever the same again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob wakes up, listening to the sound of Lyn’s laboured breathing. Across the room Lyn sits, sweating with pain, preparing an injection. We see he has used the LAST OF THE MEDICINE. He injects himself, his breathing beginning to ease and sits staring at the empty VIAL. Bob watches for a moment then shuts his eyes, feigning sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn and Bob are waiting on the quiet road which is studded with burnt out CARS. Mahmud drives an old Renault out of a warehouse and over to them. He gets out the car and hands Lyn the keys.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I really appreciate this sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn watches Mahmud in the mirror as they drive away. He stands in the middle of the road, staring at his feet. They drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car cuts across the landscape.  125 126 10/21/08 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car has pulled over at a junction.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR 126
dialogues.text: Lyn sits staring out at the emptiness, looking, perhaps for the first time, worried.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (peevish) Jesus Christ. We could’a bought a map if you’d said.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Bedouins have been navigating this desert for centuries without maps. You can use a wrist-watch in conjunction with the sun.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Well...use your watch.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I haven’t got a watch.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh for the love of...Here... He gives Lyn his watch. Lyn looks at the watch and turns to stare at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: This is a digital watch, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So? That’s...

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: So you need a watch with hands for Christ's sake!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well how the hell am I supposed to know? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bob stares 10/21/08

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re the navigation expert here. You told me you could find the way.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Will, if you'd just be quiet for Aeee

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Turns out you haven’t even got a watch! Now what the hell are we...

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Will you shut up? I don’t need a watch. I’m using Level Two.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Level Two. Intuition. We were trained to make correct decisions. Somebody runs up to you and says “There’s a fork in the road. Do we turn left or do we turn right? And you go...(snapping his fingers) “We go right!” at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just...instant?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Instant. (Snapping his fingers) Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: WE’VE BEEN SITTING HERE FOR HALF AN HOUR! HOW’S THAT “INSTANT?” 76. 126 Lyn abruptly starts the engine and takes the right turn.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s that way?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (grimly ) Yes. It’s this way.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Right. Now you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Below us the car drives off into the empty landscape, getting smaller and smaller. Then... BOOM. We see the flash of the explosion and the Renault is flipped like a toy car. A ribbon of black smoke rises into the blue sky. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB’s P.O.V - We are stumbling forward towards a sand berm. We hear the sound of heavy breathing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (croaking) What...what happened? Lyn is staggering over the sand with Bob on his back. He is holding his backpack. Bob has a gash on his forehead which is bleeding. Under the blood his face is white. In the distance, behind them, we can see the column of black smoke rising.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Improvised Explosive Device.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: You’re okay Bob. It’s gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can't believe this. Great fucking intuition Lyn. I can’t...put me down. I can walk. Put me down. Lyn puts Bob down. Bob keels sideways onto the sand and lies there, wheezing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Jeez. Oh, Jeez.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Alright, c'mon... He hauls Bob to his feet, puts his baseball cap on him and pulls him onto his back. Bob hangs there limply as Lyn sets off again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lyn reaches up and gropes at Bob’s face, removing his spectacles. Bob doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Where are we going? We should stay with the car so the army can find us.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Fedayeen will find us first.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, I disagree. I totally disagree. (Beat) The Federal what?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Fedayeen Saddam. Paramilitary. Fellas who probably laid the IED. They could be on their way now. Hold this Bob. He passes Bob his backpack. They stagger on in silence for a moment, Bob jogging up and down on Lyn’s back. Lyn snaps the legs off Bob’s glasses, uses them as improvised divining rods to scan the sand ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Could be IED’s or mines around here. I’m checking for disturbances in the telluric current.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (still dazed) Are they my glasses? Lyn doesn’t answer, keeps on walking, struggling a little under the weight. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, it’s hot. I’m so hot. (Beat) Aren’t you hot?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (not unkindly) Bob? It’s pretty important you keep your mouth closed, okay? You can lose a lot of water through an open mouth. He staggers on with him.  129 10/21/08 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob trails after Lyn, his shirt tied around his head, breathing hard. Lyn is still scanning the sand.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can’t breathe properly. I can’t...Oh boy... He staggers, manages not to fall.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: You're okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I think I’m bleeding to death.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: You’re not bleeding to death, Bob. It's shock, okay? It’s just the shock. It’ll pass. You’re gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If we’d stayed at the road we would be safe now! Now we've got no water, no food or, or... (noticing Lyn’s scanning) Will you forget about the fucking tantric currents?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (patiently) You’re going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Stop saying that! I just got blown up! I’m in the middle of a desert! I’M NOT GONNA BE OKAY!

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Bob, you’re suffering from shock. If you start panicking now your heart’s gonna stop. Bob stares after him incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (losing it) Is that...is that supposed to calm me down?! (hurrying after him) You know what color the seats were in the frigging hotel but you can’t...you wanna observe something Lyn? Observe the fucking bomb in the middle of the road! (CONTINUED)
129 Lyn walks on without answering. Bob notices the sun is sinking.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. That’s west. Al Qaim’s in that direction. We’re going the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: The mission isn’t in Al Qaim. It’s somewhere near Al Qaim.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Beat) I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is that...is that...is that a joke? We've come six hundred miles and you don’t know where we're going?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: If the exact whereabouts of the Target was known it wouldn’t take a Jedi to find them, would it? Bob watches Lyn stare around him, looking pale and drawn and, for the first time, afraid. Bob is so

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who gave you the mission Lyn? (Beat) Lyn?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Bill did.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Bill did. He appeared in my trailer two months ago. A psychic projection. I could hear him calling my name. staggered by this for a moment he can’t speak.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Softly) Oh...Oh Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: He needed me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus. Oh Jesus Lyn. There’s no mission? We’re in the middle of the desert because you heard voices? There’s no one here! There’s no-one fucking here. Lyn starts to walk off but staggers and falls.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lyn! Bob rushes to him, kneels beside him. Lyn clutches his stomach, grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it the Crohns?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I don’t have Crohns.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I’m dying. Bob stares at him, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn sits staring up at the immense MOON above them. Bob sits watching, huddled against the cold, in the shelter of some rocks. Lyn gets up, stumbles back over to him and lies down, struggling for breath, white with pain.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: It’s gone Bob. I can’t find him. I’ve lost my power. It’s the curse.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What curse?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (With profound sadness) They took this... beautiful thing we'd been building and they corrupted it. They destroyed the New Earth Army. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who destroyed it? Lyn stares at the stars above, remembering, grief stricken.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jedis, now indistinguishable from other soldiers, stand white-washing over the COSMIC MURALS. Major Holtz stands watching.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HOLTZ
dialogues.text: Yoga is not the business of the US Army, ladies. Drumming circles are not the business of the Army. And love and peace is most certainly not the business of the Army. So you girls better start thinking about how you CAN engage in the business of the United States Army, which, in case you have forgotten, involves winning fucking wars!

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When the dust of the Pendleton Affair had settled it revealed a surprising victor. INT. MAJOR HOLTZ’S OFFICE - DAY - THE PAST 132 Larry stands to attention in front of Holtz, a REPORT held under one arm.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Major Holtz regarded Larry Hooper as a patriotic whistle-blower and the one sound fruit in an otherwise dubious barrel of apples.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: It’s some scientific research I’ve done for possible offensive psi applications sir. (Beat) I did show the report to Lieutenant Colonel Django, but he didn’t seem interested. Holtz snorts angrily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HOLTZ
dialogues.text: (muttering) I bet he wasn’t. He takes the report and begins to look through it. Pause. He looks up slowly at Larry. MAJOR HOLTZ (CONT’D) We have men who can do this?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: (a sly smile) I think I know one sir. Holtz ponders the report, tempted.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HOLTZ
dialogues.text: But we don’t have the resources.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Well sir...there is goat lab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building we saw at the top of the film. A hundred GOATS stare silently at us.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Goat Lab was originally created as a clandestine laboratory to provide in-the-field surgical training for Special Forces soldiers. We BOOM down to reveal that many of the goats have their legs in PLASTER. BOB (CONT’D) (V.O.) (CONT'D) The goats would get shot in the leg with a bolt gun and then a trainee would have to dress the wound successfully. Goat lab actually used to be called Dog Lab...

dialogues.speaker: SMALL DOG STARING AT US 134
dialogues.text: -..with big, brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But it turned out most soldiers didn’t feel good shooting dogs in the leg... A SOLDIER stares doubtfully down at the dog, bolt-gun in hand.  135 136 137 10/21/08 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Goat stands tethered in the desert. TITLES read “Nevada Test Site, Frenchman Flat, 1951."

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-whereas the army had long felt fine about doing stuff to goats - even testing atomic weapons on them. We hear the drone of an AEROPLANE high, high above. The goat looks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn stands facing the goats. Holtz and Hooper watch him. Lyn STARES. One of the goats STARES BACK. Lyn STARES. The goat STARES BACK. Lyn STARES. And the Goat falls over.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HOLTZ
dialogues.text: (softly) Holy shit. Beat. The goat gets back up, shakes itself and walks off. Lyn slumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob listens transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: This was the real deal, Bob. I was at the Gateway. Afterwards I realized I'd got injured.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Sympathetic injury I guess. I was bruised all over.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So, it’s not that the goat fought back?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (sadly) Goat didn’t have a chance.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: But...that was it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I wish it was. Hooper told Holtz we should try the experiment again. Only this time they said...kill the goat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six GOATS - each wearing a NUMBERED BIB - stand in a small bare room. A SOLDIER is setting up a VIDEO CAMERA in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn sits in another bare room. Holtz and Larry Hooper stand watching him. Lyn is also being TAPED. A SOLDIER walks in carrying an envelope. Holtz takes the envelope and draws from it a piece of paper. He shows it to Lyn - the number FOUR.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HOLTZ
dialogues.text: Take out number four. Lyn stares at the number.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lyn said he had no intention of killing the goat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn flushes with indignation at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: There was no way! What had the goat ever done to me? It was totally against the way of the Jedi. I was just going to pretend to try so they would say, “okay - it can’t be done” and forget about it. But then, as I sat there, I felt this, this pulse start inside of me and...I couldn’t stop it. He turns to look at Bob, haunted. LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) You know what I keep thinking? INT. ABANDONED HOSPITAL - LYN’S ROOM - THE PAST 141

dialogues.speaker: LYN
dialogues.text: -..as he stares, concentrating. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe deep down inside some dark part of me wanted to see if I could do it?

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: Grainy, flickering black and white footage of the six goats in the room. Suddenly one of them goes down. INT. ABANDONED HOSPITAL - LYN’S ROOM - THE PAST 143 A soldier runs into the room. Holtz, Hooper and Lyn turn to him, the atmosphere electric with dread and anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (solemnly) The goat is dead. The three men stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR HOLTZ
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) Goat number four?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (surprised) No. Number five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stares at Lyn aghast.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Collateral damage?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (eyes glistening) Collateral damage. (Beat) That was it. I'd used my powers for evil and it was like I brought a curse upon us all. Like that poem where the guy kills the seagull and they make him wear it round his neck. Every night I'd dream of that goat in its little bib, it’s mouth opening and closing but nothing coming out... Bob shakes his head, stares out into the darkness. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The silence of the goats. Lyn flicks a suspicious glance at Bob, but is reassured by his solemn expression.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I finished my tour and I quit. I walked out of the unit and I never went back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn, wearing civilian clothes and holding a suitcase, is walking off the base. He reaches the gates and turns for one last look at the place that has been his home.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But before he could leave Larry arranged one last parting gift. Lyn tuns back to the gates and finds Larry Hooper standing in front of him, looking WIRED.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: What do you wan...? Before he can finish Larry CHOPS his hand down in an odd blow onto Lyn’s forehead. Lyn staggers back a little, holding his head. LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) What the hell? Larry has already darted around him with a crazy laugh and is running madly back into the base. Lyn stares after him, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was the Dim Mak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at Lyn, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The Dim Mak?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: The Dim Mak. The Quivering Palm. The Death Touch. It’s like this legendary, martial arts move. It was forbidden in the New Earth Army. Larry had got it from a mail- order book. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What does the Death Touch do?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Beat, patiently) It kills you Bob. With one touch.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: There's a story that Wong Wifu, great Chinese martial artist, had a fight with some guy and had him beat when the guy gave him this light tap, and Wong looked at him and the guy just nodded. That was it. He’d given him the death touch and Wong died.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Then and there?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: No. Eighteen years later. That’s the weird thing with Dim Mak - you never know when it’s going to take effect. He flops back, too tired to talk anymore. Bob watches him as he falls asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same horizon, the dunes now burning under the sun. We TRACK back and find Bob and Lyn lying asleep, lips cracked, dehydrated, exhausted. Faintly we hear a sound - a tinny BELL. It gets closer. Groggily Bob opens his eyes just as a GOAT walks into the frame and walks past him, the bell tied around its neck. Bob lies, watching it pass, trying to work out if it’s a hallucination. He struggles to his feet and sets off up the berm he’s been lying at the foot of. The goat walks on ahead of Bob, crests the top of the berm and disappears from sight. Bob reaches the top of the berm and stands, swaying, staring down at something. CLOSE ON BOB’S FACE - stunned.  148 149 150 10/21/08 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is dragging a barely conscious Lyn up the berm, following the goat. He staggers, barely able to put one foot in front of the other. At last we crest the top of the berm and find ourselves looking down on a WATER-HOLE, fringed with palms. The goat stands drinking. It stops to look up at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Lyn collapse into the wet mud of the hole. Bob Manages to cup some water into Lyn’s mouth and then his own. He rolls onto his back, stares up at the burning sky. We hear a dull roaring, muffled, growing in volume. A HELICOPTER is approaching... FADE OUT. In the BLACK we hear a VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY BROADCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (in Arabic, subtitled) In America if I do not like my cell-phone company I change them. I am in charge. This is consumer power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVERHEAD SHOT - Lyn and Bob lie side by side in beds, both hooked up to IV’s. Sunlight slants through the shutters on the window in the cool room. The voice is coming from a SPEAKER on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY BROADCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is democracy. Let us work together for that. And please stop shooting at those who are only here to help. Lyn opens his eyes, looks around him.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY BROADCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is an old one from Cat Stevens. (Correcting himself) Yusef Islam. That’s Yusef Islam. Lyn looks at the door and for a second there’s a FLASH OF A FACE staring in through the glass. Then it’s gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Over the speaker comes the sound of a period song. Lyn sits up, staring at the door. Bob stirs in his bed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Lyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn walks unsteadily out of the room, towing his IV drip behind him. The door at the end of the corridor is just CLOSING. Lyn sets off down the corridor. Bob appears in the doorway behind him, towing his own IV.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Hissing) Lyn? Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Lyn passes doors, glances into the rooms beyond... LYN’S P.O.V - the room seems to house a PRINTING PRESS. A SOLDIER stands with his back to us, watching LEAFLETS fire out of the press. We pass to the next room which seems to be a RECORDING STUDIO - the walls covered in shelves of CD’s. A SOLDIER sits with headphones on playing an electronic keyboard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn emerges blinking into the light. He stares around him. The song is playing over speakers, echoing eerily around the base. A door slides shut with a clang nearby and Lyn turns to locate the sound. A trail of FOOTPRINTS leads across the sand to a HANGAR nearby. Lyn heads off across the sand, dragging the IV. Bob emerges behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Lyn! Lyn reaches the sliding doors of the building and drags them open and stands staring into the gloomy interior. Bob catches him up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think we should... He stops following Lyn’s gaze...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: The place is full of GOATS. Lyn and Bob stare at the animals. Slowly Lyn advances into the darkness, peering around him. In the shadows at the back of the building a figure STIRS. Lyn walks slowly forward until he can make out the man - old, bearded, worn and wasted by years of heavy drinking. It’s BILL DJANGO. Lyn stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Choked) Hello Bill. Bill smiles hesitantly.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: Hello Lyn. Lyn is too choked with emotion for a moment to answer.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: This is Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: Hello Bob. Bob is too amazed to reply.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh good... Bob and Lyn turn to find Larry Hooper standing in the doorway behind them. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) .-.-the gang’s all here. Lyn stares at Larry - shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Bill are showing Bob and Lyn around. A few CIVILIAN WORKERS are working at computers behind them.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: This is primarily a Psyops base. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Psy for psychic?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: (Chuckling) Psy for psychological, although the irony isn’t wasted on me. Radio broadcasts, leaflets, that sort of thing. Bob picks up a LEAFLET. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) Oh, that’s an Iraqi Psyops leaflet they dropped on us.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (reading) “American Soldier - your wives are back home having sex with Bart Simpson and Bert Reynolds.”

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Yeah, hadn’t exactly done their homework there. Lyn is staring at Bill who is looking a little vacantly at the racks of CD’s. Larry notices. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) How'd you find us, Lyn?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I remote viewed you. Larry smiles a little mockingly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If this is Psyops what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: I said primarily Psyops. This is a restricted area, you understand? Everything you hear and see stays secret or you go to prison. Bob nods a little nervously. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) There are individuals in the current administration who are looking for...creative solutions for the War on Terror. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) They're far more open minded then their predecessors, and they’ve out-sourced experimental research to my company. He indicates the PSIC name badge he’s wearing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: “Sick?”

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: It’s pronounced psi-ike. Psychic Systems International Corp. Turns out certain people had heard about the New Earth Army and were interested in some of the work we were doing back then. They got in touch with me, I got in touch with Bill.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (To Bill) You’re working for him? Bill frowns at the CDs, not seeming to hear.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Bill’s been looking into subliminal messaging. (Selecting a disc) This is one we’ve designed to play to our own troops before combat. He puts the disc in a player and presses play. We hear a burst of a period song.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: There’s a subliminal message in this?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: (reading the CD) This is...”Don’t get drunk before firing heavy machine guns.” We’ve got all sort of products in development.(To Worker) Tell them one of our new ideas.

dialogues.speaker: PSIC WORKER
dialogues.text: Air bag mine?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Air bag mine. Non-lethal mine, catapults the fucker up into air. (To another) Gimme another one.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND PSIC WORKER
dialogues.text: Blast target with pheromones and then release Attack Bees. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Excellent. Attack Bees. The Forces of Nature! Another.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST PSIC WORKER
dialogues.text: Project Achilles. We mutilate enemy corpses and...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: We’re not doing that anymore! (Throwing an eraser at the worker) Idiot! He turns back to Lyn. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) The point is we've got a budget, we've got supporters. I’m rebuilding the New Earth Army. Only this time without the hippy crap. Bill stands up and starts walking a little unsteadily towards the door. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) You okay Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (Without turning) Gonna get some ice-cream. Larry waits until Bill has left before turning back to Lyn.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: You get the odd flash of what he used to be but... he’s pretty burnt out with the booze. Larry shakes his head in apparent sorrow. Then he notices some candy on a desk. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) Ooo, Twizzlers. He picks it up and starts to eat it. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) (To Lyn) You want one? Lyn shakes his head, trying not to show the emotions he is feeling. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) (Watching him) God, I love these things...  155 156 157 10/21/08 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob helps Lyn down the corridor. Lyn suddenly stops, listening. There is a faint sound of MUSIC coming from somewhere nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn walks down the corridor, Bob following. At the end of the corridor is a single door with a SPY-HOLE. The loud music is coming from there. We can hear now that it is an annoying children’s show song or heavy metal. We TRACK towards the door... Lyn hesitates then slides back the SPY-HOLE cover and peers in. LYN’S P.O.V - An IRAQI PRISONER sits huddled in the cell, illuminated in the flashes of a powerful STROBE LIGHT OVERHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: SONG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (Lyrics from chosen song.) The prisoner looks terrified, and despite the whimsical music the whole scene is horribly sinister. Lyn steps away from the spy-hole.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Anxiously) What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: It’s the Dark Side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn sits on his bed, as low as we’ve ever seen him. Bob watches him, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Lyn stares at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lyn? What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: It's too late...I’m dying, Bob. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re not dying! I don’t believe you can kill someone with a mail order Dim Sum. You can’t...

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: Dim Mak.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Whatever. I don’t believe you can just...

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: It’s cancer.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: just tap someone and ...it...(Beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I mean, I know it was caused by the Dim Mak. But...it’s...you know...it’s cancer. That’s what the doctors say. Different ways of looking at...different names for a reality or, or uh... He lapses into silence. Bob is stunned. Lyn lies down. LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) I shouldn’t have come Bob. Shouldn’t have come. Lyn pulls the EAGLE FEATHER from the chain around his neck. LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) ...Give this back to Bill...I don’t deserve it. Bob stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Django sits cross-legged in the sand, drinking from a bottle of whiskey, watching the sun set. Bob marches up to him, stands awkward but determined.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I think you should go and see Lyn, sir. (Beat) he needs you. Bill doesn’t answer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The man crossed a desert to see you again. Bill takes a long drink, stares at the sky. Bob watches him with mounting frustration.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, he told me all these stories about Bill Django, and I was pretty excited to meet you, but I’ve gotta tell you...you’re one big disappointment. Bill doesn’t react. Bob starts to walk away then turns back, and throws the FEATHER down at Bill’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He told me to give you that back. I don’t know why. Its supposed to be a mark of honour isn’t it? I don’t see how you deserve that. Beat. Bill turns to look at Bob for the first time. He takes a long drink.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (Beat) It isn’t real.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: The feather. Twenty thousand dollar fine for taking an eagle feather. This one’s off a turkey. You just die the tip black. (Beat) Don’t tell Lyn. Bill stares at the feather. BILL DJANGO (CONT’D) None of it was real.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Angrily) That isn’t true. That isn’t true. He looks around for inspiration - notices a LONE CLOUD floating in the sky. Bob places his fingers on his temples and STARES at the cloud, focuses, desperate, hopeful... Bill notices and watches, curious. Slowly, the cloud fades and DISAPPEARS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bob can’t believe it. He looks at Bill who is staring at him. He has tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn lies sleeping. Larry sits at the foot of his bed, smoking a cigar. He watches Lyn for a moment, then COUGHS deliberately. Nothing. He repeats the cough - louder. Lyn wakes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Oh. Didn’t mean to wake you. The two men stare at each other. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) Heard you weren't feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Beat) Just tired.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: How'd you find us?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I told you. I remote viewed you.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Scotty Mercer told you, didn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Yeah, he did. We told Scotty we were coming over here, asked him if he wanted some work.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen Scotty.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: That’s funny, because he told me he’d run into you and mentioned that there might be some jobs going with us over here. (Beat) Isn’t that why you came, really, Lyn? You want back in, don’t you? Lyn stares at him, disturbed, afraid this might be true. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) It can happen. You’ve only got to say the word. Could be the new Golden Age for Psi research. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) You, me and Bill, back together again. Just like the old days. Larry closes his eyes, trying to remember something. LARRY HOOPER (CONT’D) Mother Earth, my life support system. As a soldier I must drink your blue water, live inside your red clay and eat your green skin. Lyn listens, moved despite himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Bob stand on a picnic table, under the full moon. Bill is leading Bob through some YOGA POSITIONS. Both are drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I pray my boots will always kiss your face and my footsteps match your heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn can’t help but join in the prayer.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY AND LYN
dialogues.text: Carry my body through space and time. You are my connection to the Universe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Bob both stand in a difficult position - balanced on one leg.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY AND LYN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -..-and all that comes after. I am yours and you are mine. As we watch Bill slowly topples forward off the table and crashes out of sight below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men finish the prayer.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY AND LYN
dialogues.text: I salute you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: (Beat) Don’t make a decision now. Tell me in the morning. He pats Lyn’s leg, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is holding a concussed Bill who has a cut on his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Bill? Bill are you okay? Bill opens his eyes suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: I just saw Timothy Leary.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (beat) Timothy Leary’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: I know. He’s had an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Bob head down the corridor. They pass a SOLDIER.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (Saluting) Good evening sir.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (Mumbling) Getting some ice-cream. They walk on and reach the doors to the KITCHENS. The two men hesitate, look at each other... Then Bob walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PSIC WORKERS AND PSYOPS TROOPS are all eating breakfast together, talking, laughing. Bob and Bill sit drinking coffee. Lyn appears with a tray and sits down beside Bob. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They eat in silence for a moment. Lyn turns to look out of the window to where Larry Hooper stands outside in the early morning sun, smoking a cigar and drinking coffee. He turns and notices Lyn, raises his cup, smiles. Lyn looks troubled. Bob suddenly leans into Lyn.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (Softly) Don’t eat the jello. Lyn turns to Bob puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don’t eat the jello. Lyn tries to puzzle this out but is distracted by Larry outside who seems to have noticed something in the sand at his feet - a small insect of some kind. He begins to watch it with strange fascination. After a moment he sinks to his knees in order to get a better look at it. One of the SOLDIERS notices and starts to laugh softly. His neighbor looks at him as if he’s crazy then begins to laugh himself. Lyn looks around him, sensing the strange atmosphere creeping through the room.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: We put LSD in the jello. Lyn turns to stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Bill showed me where Larry had bottles of LSD. So we put it in the jello mix last night.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (Suddenly) And in the water. Bob turns to stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: I put it in the main water tank as well. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bob stares at him, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: But...we’ve drunk the water.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: (Thoughtfully) Yeah. He pours himself another coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY BROADCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (Into microphone) The weather? The weather is going to be HOT! Through the window we see Larry get on his belly to get a better look at the bug. INT. RADIO STATION —- MORNING 167 The DJ SOLDIER has gone off script. A PRODUCER is trying ineffectually to pull him away from the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY BROADCASTER
dialogues.text: (Into microphone) I’m guessing. I mean, I haven’t looked at the, the thing but I'd say it’s going to be fucking HOT! Hot. Hot. Hot. The Producer pulls and releases the DJ’s headphones so they slap against his head and starts giggling.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY BROADCASTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That hurt Greg, you fucking dip- shit. (Laughing too)You fuckity fuck dip-shit fuck-hole. (Remembering something) Hey! Music! He hits a button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a LOUDSPEAKER - blasting a period song out over the base. We BOOM down to where two SOLDIERS are dancing, tripping.

dialogues.speaker: ALL OVER THE BASE
dialogues.text: Soldiers are wandering around, talking, some falling to their knees, weak with laughter. Some stand alone, staring with a beatific smile at the sky. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As the music plays on a STRYKER ARMORED VEHICLE drives around the corner of a building, a SOLDIER standing up, arms raised, in the gun turret. The Stryker screeches into a clumsy skid, the Soldier having to hang on. The Stryker roars off again, heading straight for the GATES of the base.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (calling down into the vehicle) You’re going to hit the gates. You’re going to hit the gates. The Stryker veers left and smashes through the perimeter fence and out into the desert.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calmly) It's okay. You missed them. INT. RADIO STATION —- MORNING 169 The DJ and the Producer are wrestling over the sound desk, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Bill walk towards the cell block.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (angry) Don’t you think it might have been more sensible if we hadn't drunk the fucking water?

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: That might have aroused suspicion. But don’t worry. Over the years I have built up a massive tolerance to all narcotics. INT. CELL —- MORNING 171 An IRAQI PRISONER looks up startled as the door to the cell is flung open and Bill stands, filling the doorway, bare-chested, wild-eyed and wild-haired.

dialogues.speaker: BILL DJANGO
dialogues.text: In the name of the New Earth Army and loving people everywhere I’m liberating this base!  172 173 174 10/21/08 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyn slides open the door to the shed and begins to shoo the goats out into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the music continues Bob, Lyn and Bill appear leading a column of nervous IRAQI PRISONERS out of the building, towards the gates. Lyn and Bill are holding BABY GOATS in their ARMS. A tripping Bob is holding bunches of flowers it’s as close as they can get to the illustration from the New Earth Army Manual. Lyn holds up a hand to stop the procession. Larry stands in front of them, a GUN in his hand, his face blank. Lyn and Larry stare at each other. Then, unexpectedly, Larry starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (softly) Give me the gun Larry. Larry starts to raise the gun to his mouth. Pauses. Scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY HOOPER
dialogues.text: Wow. I’m hungry. He wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY DJ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (Over loudspeaker, laughing) Hey! More music! (muffled) Get off, will ya? Over the loud-speakers we hear the opening of a period song.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Beat, relieved) Okay, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: FLATTENED SECTION OF FENCE 174
dialogues.text: Bob and Lyn stand at one side, Bill at the other, beckoning the prisoners through, hugging the prisoners as they pass through.

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: We're very sorry. Ma'assalama. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: One by one the Iraqis walk out through the broken fence, staring around them suspiciously, expecting a trap. Nothing happens, no one shoots them. LYN CASSADY (CONT’D) (waving) That's it. Keep going. Ma'assalama. The Iraqis start to hurry away over the sand. Beyond them we can the Stryker, driving in circles in the desert, a NAKED SOLDIER stands whooping on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, tripping heavily, is staring with fascination at the sand trickling through his fingers. Suddenly we hear the building whine of the HELICOPTER engine starting up. Bob looks up, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER 176
dialogues.text: Bill and Lyn sit in the chopper, Bill at the controls. Lyn is holding the flowers. Bob appears, hurrying over.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (calling) Wait! Wait for me! Where are you going...what about the mission?

dialogues.speaker: LYN CASSADY
dialogues.text: (Over the sound of the engine) You are the mission Bob! You are the mission! Tell them what happened! The helicopter begins to rise. Bob stands swaying, staring up. Lyn smiles sadly through the window, raises his hand. The Helicopter RISES - HIGHER AND HIGHER. Bob waves goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At the time I was hurt that Lyn hadn't taken me with him. But now I know it was because he and Bill had already seen what was to come.  177 178 179 180 10/21/08 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the helicopter flies off into the blue.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nobody knows exactly what happened. The official story is that their helicopter must have crashed, either because they were hit by an RPG or because...well, that’s what happens when you fly a helicopter while you’re tripping on acid. All I know is they’ve never been seen since. Like all Shaman they returned to the sky. The helicopter disappears altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEEKS LATER. Bob sits typing, frowning with concentration.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I got back home I wrote the story up. Everything. EXT. OUTSIDE BOB’S OLD HOUSE - EVENING 179 Bob sits in his car staring at his old home, across the road. Through the window we can see Bob’s ex-wife Debora, eating dinner with Bob’s ex-Editor - Dave.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I sent it to the newspapers, the radio stations, the TV stations, because that was what Lyn wanted me to do. The people needed to know. INT. BOB’S APARTMENT - EVENING 180 Bob sits watching a Today style show on TV.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was ready for whatever they would do to me. I was ready to disappear. I was ready to go to prison. I was a Jedi and I was fighting for the New Earth Army. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (Beat) But they didn’t put me in prison. They did something much worse.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: (chuckling) And finally, US forces in Iraq are using what some are calling a cruel and unusual tool to break the resistance of Iraqi POWs, and Many parents would agree! Some prisoners are being forced to listen to Barney the Purple Dinosaur sing the I Love You song. I think after an hour of that they’1l spill the beans! Don’t you? Let’s go outside to Al for the weather. Bob watches, ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is working for another small town newspaper. He sits at his desk, staring fixedly ahead at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was it. That was the only bit of my story that ran anywhere. And it was a joke. And if I ever needed proof of how the Dark Side have taken the beautiful dream of what a nation could be and had twisted it, destroyed it, that was it. Bob stands up. He starts to walk down the office, his face set with grim determination.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S EDITOR
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I won't stop. I won’t give up. Bob quickens his pace. BOB (CONT’D) (V.O.) (CONT'D) Because when I look at what is happening in the world, I know that now, more than ever, we need to become ALL that we can BE. Bob is running. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, more than ever, we need the Supermen. Bob rushes towards the WALL. Just as he is about to hit it we FREEZE FRAME. We hear the opening of a period song.
